content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: We use to crawl around the woods of Key Largo looking for smugglers. I saw a few Black Widows. Actually it was the Brown Recluse that freaked me out the most. Don As well it should. The brown recluse's venom is far more dangerous than the black widow's is. Widow venom is painful, but it doesn't do massive tissue damage, (as the brown recluse's does). They're really only dangerous to kids and the elderly. Widows can be found everywhere here in the west. They're not that big a deal, their webs are easy to identify and thus they're easy to find and exterminate. Recluses are worse. They don't stay in a web, they hide, and they wander at night. Their venom can cause ya to potentially lose a digit or part of a limb, as it's a necrotoxin.
quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: We use to crawl around the woods of Key Largo looking for smugglers. I saw a few Black Widows. Actually it was the Brown Recluse that freaked me out the most. Don

They're not that big a deal, their webs are easy to identify and thus they're easy to find and exterminate. Recluses are worse. They don't stay in a web, they hide, and they wander at night. title: 'World's Deadliest Spider' Found in Whole Foods Produce Section

content: On the Big Island of Hawaii, in the sourthern region lurks one of this bad boys cousins. He looks the same minus the hair, instead he has a aerodescent exoskeleton that reflects the colors around himself. I never knew what a bad azz he was until one day when the new issue of National Geographic came in the mail. There on the front cover was our lil Big Island monster. "The worlds most ferocious spider" read the title. I have had run ins with this quarter sized spider before and knew he was a feerless lil guy but did not know he was listed as the worlds most ferocious. With eyes much like our guy shown in the photo above and a independent moving head on a neck much like that of a humans he is very intriguing. He is also the Navy Seal of spiders, only the size of a quarter with a bite that measures 1/2 an inch, the ability to leap about six inches and a attitude, he lays no web and hunts for his prey, he will stalk anything, even humans. I have played with him on several occasions using a pencil to prod him. He is very smart and recognises that the pencil is merely a tool, his interest was not in the pencil but in me, he tried in vain to bite me over and over ignoring the pencil. Eventually I tired of playing with him and he met Mr. Nike, but of all the spiders I have ever seen, this guy takes the cake. He is without a doubt the most beautiful, ferocious and cunning of all. If you ever visit the Big Island of Hawaii beware of this spider while in the southern region. I lived on the Big Island for about four years and only saw him in that area. I have never seen him anywhere else in our State and even though I live on Kauai, I am always aware of this lil bad boy out there lurking somewhere, I know he fears nothing and is heavily armed.

He looks the same minus the hair, instead he has a aerodescent exoskeleton that reflects the colors around himself. I never knew what a bad azz he was until one day when the new issue of National Geographic came in the mail. There on the front cover was our lil Big Island monster. "The worlds most ferocious spider" read the title. I have had run ins with this quarter sized spider before and knew he was a feerless lil guy but did not know he was listed as the worlds most ferocious. With eyes much like our guy shown in the photo above and a independent moving head on a neck much like that of a humans he is very intriguing. He is also the Navy Seal of spiders, only the size of a quarter with a bite that measures 1/2 an inch, the ability to leap about six inches and a attitude, he lays no web and hunts for his prey, he will stalk anything, even humans. I have played with him on several occasions using a pencil to prod him. I actually appreciate Spiders. Here is New York we have a little harmless taratualla called the American Wolf spider. They're not poisonious to us, and cannot even break the skin. In fact they don't want to bite. We're not food and they know it. But I convinced my land lord to stop using the exterminator with his sprays, and I released a female with her egg case in the building. Once the "kids" hatched, within a few weeks, all, and I mean ALL the roaches were gone. I rarely even see one now, but they're around - but there are no roaches around. Dave

title: 'World's Deadliest Spider' Found in Whole Foods Produce Section

content: quote: I actually appreciate Spiders. Here is New York we have a little harmless taratualla called the American Wolf spider. They're not poisonious to us, and cannot even break the skin. In fact they don't want to bite. We're not food and they know it. But I convinced my land lord to stop using the exterminator with his sprays, and I released a female with her egg case in the building. Once the "kids" hatched, within a few weeks, all, and I mean ALL the roaches were gone. I rarely even see one now, but they're around - but there are no roaches around. Dave Dave we have those also, I don't kill them and let them roam in the house. Like you say, they are harmless and I have never heard of someone being bit by one. They are hunters also so they are pretty clean lil guys. They freak out my duaghter becuase of their size and look but I am slowly getting her used to the idea that they are good to have around. Here in the tropics it is impossible to be bug free and these Wolf spiders( alot of people here call them Cane siders) are a big help in ridding the house of the truly undesirable pest.

content: Thats not the worlds deadliest spider....Some ******* in Australia holds that title.... The aforementioned spider doesn't even have its fangs exposed....the Australian funnel web has 1 inch fangs that will go through boots.

title: 'World's Deadliest Spider' Found in Whole Foods Produce Section

content: We have one spider here, about the size of a quarter that will chase you. Its bite is poisonous but not deadly. Its called a "Hobo" spider, and its not a native U.S. species. We also have black widows, brown recluses, and a few others. When fall comes around I set out sticky traps made just for spiders, in every corner, nook, and cranny in the house. Then come spring when it warms up and they go back outside. I wear leather gloves to pick up and toss the traps. DANG! I hate spiders!!
reply: We have one spider here, about the size of a quarter that will chase you. Its bite is poisonous but not deadly. Its called a "Hobo" spider, and its not a native U.S. species. content: Iam lucky i got thousands of lizards who feast on the roaches and bugs. so I don't got a major bug problem. and i got a few wasp nest that hunt spiders. BTW I don't suggest any of you start placing pest eaters if you don't know what they will do in the long run. There a island some place near bora bora I think who had a major rat problem so they brought in a bunch of cat's in. The rat's were soon gone but the cat's were soon producing more then the island can handle so they brought in a prison frog and soon the cat's where all gone now but that little group of frogs now number in the thousands.

content: quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: We use to crawl around the woods of Key Largo looking for smugglers. I saw a few Black Widows. Actually it was the Brown Recluse that freaked me out the most. Don As well it should. The brown recluse's venom is far more dangerous than the black widow's is. Widow venom is painful, but it doesn't do massive tissue damage, (as the brown recluse's does). They're really only dangerous to kids and the elderly. Widows can be found everywhere here in the west. They're not that big a deal, their webs are easy to identify and thus they're easy to find and exterminate. Recluses are worse. They don't stay in a web, they hide, and they wander at night. Their venom can cause ya to potentially lose a digit or part of a limb, as it's a necrotoxin.
quote: Originally posted by 21yrsUSCGUSCS: We use to crawl around the woods of Key Largo looking for smugglers. I saw a few Black Widows. Actually it was the Brown Recluse that freaked me out the most. Don
reply: As well it should. The brown recluse's venom is far more dangerous than the black widow's is. Widow venom is painful, but it doesn't do massive tissue damage, (as the brown recluse's does). They're really only dangerous to kids and the elderly. Widows can be found everywhere here in the west. They're not that big a deal, their webs are easy to identify and thus they're easy to find and exterminate. Recluses are worse. They don't stay in a web, they hide, and they wander at night. Their venom can cause ya to potentially lose a digit or part of a limb, as it's a necrotoxin.

title: 'World's Deadliest Spider' Found in Whole Foods Produce Section

content: On the Big Island of Hawaii, in the sourthern region lurks one of this bad boys cousins. He looks the same minus the hair, instead he has a aerodescent exoskeleton that reflects the colors around himself. I never knew what a bad azz he was until one day when the new issue of National Geographic came in the mail. There on the front cover was our lil Big Island monster. "The worlds most ferocious spider" read the title. I have had run ins with this quarter sized spider before and knew he was a feerless lil guy but did not know he was listed as the worlds most ferocious. With eyes much like our guy shown in the photo above and a independent moving head on a neck much like that of a humans he is very intriguing. He is also the Navy Seal of spiders, only the size of a quarter with a bite that measures 1/2 an inch, the ability to leap about six inches and a attitude, he lays no web and hunts for his prey, he will stalk anything, even humans. I have played with him on several occasions using a pencil to prod him. He is very smart and recognises that the pencil is merely a tool, his interest was not in the pencil but in me, he tried in vain to bite me over and over ignoring the pencil. Eventually I tired of playing with him and he met Mr. Nike, but of all the spiders I have ever seen, this guy takes the cake. He is without a doubt the most beautiful, ferocious and cunning of all. If you ever visit the Big Island of Hawaii beware of this spider while in the southern region. I lived on the Big Island for about four years and only saw him in that area. I have never seen him anywhere else in our State and even though I live on Kauai, I am always aware of this lil bad boy out there lurking somewhere, I know he fears nothing and is heavily armed.

I never knew what a bad azz he was until one day when the new issue of National Geographic came in the mail. There on the front cover was our lil Big Island monster. "The worlds most ferocious spider" read the title. I have had run ins with this quarter sized spider before and knew he was a feerless lil guy but did not know he was listed as the worlds most ferocious. With eyes much like our guy shown in the photo above and a independent moving head on a neck much like that of a humans he is very intriguing. He is also the Navy Seal of spiders, only the size of a quarter with a bite that measures 1/2 an inch, the ability to leap about six inches and a attitude, he lays no web and hunts for his prey, he will stalk anything, even humans. I have played with him on several occasions using a pencil to prod him. I actually appreciate Spiders. Here is New York we have a little harmless taratualla called the American Wolf spider. They're not poisonious to us, and cannot even break the skin. In fact they don't want to bite. We're not food and they know it. But I convinced my land lord to stop using the exterminator with his sprays, and I released a female with her egg case in the building. Once the "kids" hatched, within a few weeks, all, and I mean ALL the roaches were gone. I rarely even see one now, but they're around - but there are no roaches around. Dave

title: 'World's Deadliest Spider' Found in Whole Foods Produce Section

content: quote: I actually appreciate Spiders. Here is New York we have a little harmless taratualla called the American Wolf spider. They're not poisonious to us, and cannot even break the skin. In fact they don't want to bite. We're not food and they know it. But I convinced my land lord to stop using the exterminator with his sprays, and I released a female with her egg case in the building. Once the "kids" hatched, within a few weeks, all, and I mean ALL the roaches were gone. I rarely even see one now, but they're around - but there are no roaches around. Dave Dave we have those also, I don't kill them and let them roam in the house. Like you say, they are harmless and I have never heard of someone being bit by one. They are hunters also so they are pretty clean lil guys. They freak out my duaghter becuase of their size and look but I am slowly getting her used to the idea that they are good to have around. Here in the tropics it is impossible to be bug free and these Wolf spiders( alot of people here call them Cane siders) are a big help in ridding the house of the truly undesirable pest.

He, heh, I think I live in the only raoch free building in the Lower East Side... When I tell my neighbors, they all freak out. content: Thats not the worlds deadliest spider....Some ******* in Australia holds that title.... The aforementioned spider doesn't even have its fangs exposed....the Australian funnel web has 1 inch fangs that will go through boots.

title: 'World's Deadliest Spider' Found in Whole Foods Produce Section

content: We have one spider here, about the size of a quarter that will chase you. Its bite is poisonous but not deadly. Its called a "Hobo" spider, and its not a native U.S. species. We also have black widows, brown recluses, and a few others. When fall comes around I set out sticky traps made just for spiders, in every corner, nook, and cranny in the house. Then come spring when it warms up and they go back outside. I wear leather gloves to pick up and toss the traps. DANG! I hate spiders!!
reply: We have one spider here, about the size of a quarter that will chase you. Its bite is poisonous but not deadly. Its called a "Hobo" spider, and its not a native U.S. species. content: Iam lucky i got thousands of lizards who feast on the roaches and bugs. so I don't got a major bug problem. and i got a few wasp nest that hunt spiders. BTW I don't suggest any of you start placing pest eaters if you don't know what they will do in the long run. There a island some place near bora bora I think who had a major rat problem so they brought in a bunch of cat's in. The rat's were soon gone but the cat's were soon producing more then the island can handle so they brought in a prison frog and soon the cat's where all gone now but that little group of frogs now number in the thousands.
